globals.name: Buffer
globals.desc:
• {Function}

Used to handle binary data. See the buffer section.

globals.name: clearImmediate
globals.desc: clearImmediate is described in the timers section.

globals.name: clearInterval
globals.desc: clearInterval is described in the timers section.

globals.name: clearTimeout
globals.desc: clearTimeout is described in the timers section.

globals.name: console
globals.desc:
• {Object}

Used to print to stdout and stderr. See the console section.

globals.name: global
globals.desc:
• {Object} The global namespace object.

In browsers, the top-level scope is the global scope. This means that within the browser var something will define a new global variable. In Node.js this is different. The top-level scope is not the global scope; var something inside a Node.js module will be local to that module.

globals.name: process
globals.desc:
• {Object}

The process object. See the process object section.

globals.name: setImmediate
globals.desc: setImmediate is described in the timers section.

globals.name: setInterval
globals.desc: setInterval is described in the timers section.

globals.name: setTimeout
globals.desc: setTimeout is described in the timers section.

methods.name: require
methods.desc: This variable may appear to be global but is not. See require().

miscs.name: Global Objects
miscs.desc:
These objects are available in all modules. The following variables may appear to be global but are not. They exist only in the scope of modules, see the module system documentation:

  • __dirname
  • __filename
  • exports
  • module
  • require()

The objects listed here are specific to Node.js. There are a number of built-in objects that are part of the JavaScript language itself, which are also globally accessible.

In browsers, the top-level scope is the global scope. This means that within the browser var something will define a new global variable. In Node.js this is different. The top-level scope is not the global scope; var something inside a Node.js module will be local to that module.
